tasks.title: Manage conflict
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 1 Task 1: Manage conflict
tasks.content:
--- Domain 1 Task 1 ---

-: In this video, I'm gonna be talking
about Domain 1: Task 1, manage conflict.
So, let's get into it.
Managing conflicts.
You know, I personally believe that project management
shouldn't be called project management.
It should be called problem management, right?
Because managing a conflict is all about managing problem.
Throughout the day,
you're gonna be managing a lot of problems.
I manage a ton of projects here at TIA.
Running a school means I'm gonna be managing
a lot of conflicts.
And basically when I pick up the phone
and I call my assistant,
I call a director of location.
First thing I'm gonna do, any problems?
Why? Because I know there's gonna be some kind of conflict.
And as a project manager,
you have to be ready to manage these conflicts.
It's just the nature of the work.
It's welcome to project management.
You don't like problems.
I think you brought the wrong course because if you,
but if you love solving problems,
that's what this is about.
I am a hundred percent sure you're gonna have quite
a few questions on your exam about managing conflicts
between team members, between a customer and a team member,
between you and a team member, between you and a sponsor,
you and a functional manager, a functional manager
and a team member.
Every possible combination we can think about,
they can ask you when it comes
to managing conflicts amongst team members.
Now, let's take a look
at what PMI wants us to know.
So the first thing up, manage conflicts.
What the first thing you're gonna be able
to do is you wanna interpret
that particular source and stage of the conflict.
You wanna say to yourself,
where did this conflict come from?
What started the conflict?
And then you wanna know the stage of the conflict,
like how much has it escalated?
One of the main things with being a good project manager
is you don't want conflicts to escalate too high up.
Escalation means harder to deescalate it.
Think about this.
If two, if let's say two team members are having an issue,
what programming method should we use?
And you come to solve the problem.
The earlier you're there is
the less shouting that's happening.
Because at the beginning of a conflict,
everyone is pretty open-minded or they may be
willing to listen, but the more they talk
and the more they get angry with each other,
hey, the harder it is gonna get to solve
because it's gonna be harder to deescalate it.
So, we wanna know where that conflict happened
and what is the stage of the conflict,
where it's in right now.
What's the context?
Why did the conflict occur? Right?
First of all, look at the source.
Where did it come from?
What started it?
What's the stage?
What's the conflict?
What's being affected on a project?
Then finally, evaluate, recommend and reconcile
the appropriate conflict solution.
So, you're gonna have to evaluate this conflict.
You're gonna probably recommend or come up with ways
or come up with some kind of reconciliation
between the people on the conflict to solve it.
That's how you would fix this.
Now, I'm gonna give you guys the exam tip.
Here's the exam tip.
On any exam question,
where you have to solve a conflict
between any type of team, any type of team or stakeholders,
whatever combination you want.
The answer is always gonna be to involve people
in the solution
and use tools that are inclusive, not exclusive.
This is something we talked about in our agile section.
So, for example, Bob and Jane is having a problem,
that'll be the question.
They couldn't decide on what method to program the software.
What should you do as a project manager?
One of the choices is gonna say,
determine the best solution,
and tell them what it is, that's wrong,
'cause now you're not including them.
You're doing it yourself.
Speak to Bob and find out what his solution
and if you agree with it, implement that.
That's wrong because now you're not including Jane.
Speak to Jane and not include Bob.
That's wrong.
The answer would be to bring the team together
and then come up with a solution that makes sense for both
of them by having them doing a face-to-face discussion,
something that's inclusive, bringing them in.
That's the answer.
Now you're gonna get a lot
of questions on your exam about managing conflicts.
Remember, I can't emphasize this enough,
any choice that you see, ask yourself this question,
is this the inclusive choice?
Is this the choice
that includes everyone joining in
and helping out to come up with a solution?
Is this the choice that includes them participating?
That's gonna be the answer.
So, remember that when it comes to solving any type
of question on your exam about managing a conflict.

tasks.title: Lead a team
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 1 Task 2: Lead a team
tasks.content:
--- Domain 1 Task 2 ---

-: In this video,
I'm gonna be going over domain one: People,
task two: Lead a Team.
So in particularly task two.
It is part of any project manager's job to lead the team.
The team will look up to you.
The team will look at you for the vision.
They would look at you to help solve conflicts.
They look at you to know what to do next
on traditional projects.
You'll help to remove impediments and obstacles
on an Agile project while being a servant leader.
So there are some really important things we need to know
as being a project manager
in order to have a successful project.
You gotta remember something.
The work on a project is done by the team
not the project manager.
As a project manager, we're not gonna paint the wall,
we're not gonna code that application.
Who's gonna do that? The team is who's gonna do that.
We need to lead the team
to successfully build that application,
to successfully paint that wall and so on.
So in this particular task
PMI has given us quite a few enablers.
This is actually one of the largest tasks of those 35 tasks.
Let's take a look at what they are.
We'll go through each one of them.
So here I have all of the different things
that we need to take a look at.
And the first thing up when leading a team
is you want to set a clear vision and a mission.
A team must know what this project is about.
They must know the end product.
You must learn to think backwards to show them that vision.
Tell them, at the end
this is what the product should look like.
This is how it's gonna help the organization.
Let them know what's expected of them.
Let them know the mission of what this product will do
and the vision of how it's gonna help the organization.
When a team feels that what they're doing means something
to that business, they feel more responsible.
They start taking more responsibility for the work
that they're about to embrace on.
The next thing you wanna do,
support diversity and inclusion.
You're gonna have to remember that in today's world
you're gonna have a lot of different people
with different backgrounds, different cultures,
even in fact, different languages,
especially on virtual teams,
different behavior types, thought process.
You're gonna wanna make sure that you support this.
We talked about this in Agile.
Use tools that are inclusive, not exclusive.
Try to do things when you're talking to the team.
When you're negotiating with a team,
when you're leading with a team, try to have people talk.
Try to do discussions where everyone is included
and you're not just there speaking to someone.
When it comes to problem,
and we talked about in the previous task,
when it comes to problems and resolving conflicts,
inclusion is always the way to go.
In Agile, we talked about value servant leadership.
Servant leadership is quote-unquote,
"fetching food and water."
Removing impediments and obstacles from your team.
Expect a question on your exam
where they're gonna give you some kind of problem.
And the answer's probably gonna be
where the project manager solves it themself
and doesn't provide it to the team.
I'll give you guys a tip on this.
I've seen a question like this.
And if you come to some kind of issue
where it's an issue where the team has good inputs
and the team can solve it, let the team solve it.
If it comes to some kind of issue
where it's an administrative problem
or administrative issue that belongs to the organization
or the project manager, fix it.
Don't give it to the team.
This is how you're gonna remove impediments.
Remove obstacles. Let the team do what they do best.
If they're programmers, let them program.
Let them solve problems related to programming,
not to clericals or administrative updating plan type thing.
Okay, the next thing here is we want to know what type
of leadership style are we gonna be.
A directive leader? Are we gonna be a collaborative leader?
You have to know when to use one over the other.
Now for example, if you're doing a project
like building a large skyscraper and regulations are in play
and the work has to be done in a particular order
to a particular standard or regulatory law,
then it's probably good to be a directive leader
when you're directing the team.
This is what we must get done. There's no collaboration.
If the law says that this wall has to be painted green
because of some kind of safety regulation,
there's no collaboration on this.
They must do this. This is being a directive leader.
Collaborative leaders now,
if there is an issue on a software
where there might be multiple correct solutions
and we gotta choose one of these,
then it's good to do an inclusive collaborative solution.
Bring the team together, have them talk it out
and they'll find the right solution.
Always remember what I told you in Agile,
let the team fix it.
That's the answer. Always let the team fix it.
But remember, on certain projects with directive
where regulations are involved, you might just not do that.
Inspire, motivate, and

tasks.title: Support team performance
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 1 Task 3: Support team performance
tasks.content:
--- Domain 1 Task 3 ---

-: In this video,
I'm gonna be talking about task domain one task three,
which is support team performance.
When a team starts to work, you're gonna have to ensure
that you support them in getting the work done.
This is one of the tenets of being a servant leader.
Being a servant leader is to remove obstacles
and impediments and fetching food and water,
giving them the tools
and the space they need to be successful.
But as you're managing the team,
you have to be able to ensure
that that team performs at a level
that's getting the project work done in a timely manner
and in a manner that's satisfiable
to the basically the bosses or the sponsors
or the customers on that project.
Let's take a look at what this particular one is about.
So the first thing up we have
is appraise team members' performance
against key performance indicators.
We have to assess our team
against some kind of KPI, key performance indicators,
that we have set up.
Now, KPIs could be something as simple
as how much work they're getting done,
how fast they're getting it done.
A KPI could be how much disagreements they may be having.
So let's say you are doing an Agile project
and the team's velocity
is around let's say 50 points per iteration,
and they're doing that 50 points per iteration
over and over and over.
So that would be a KPI that you can set up
so you can measure their performance
if they're getting 50 points' worth of work done.
So you have to look at,
you have to measure their performance against something.
You can't just look at them and says,
"Oh they're doing well, or they're not doing well."
There has to be some kind of objective measurement
that we can use.
Not so much subjective, but something objective,
something numerical, something that people can agree with.
Something that we can look back on
and say, "Okay, so that's how they're doing."
We have to know this is gonna tell us are they working good?
Do they need more coaching?
Do they need more training?
Because if we don't know this,
then how would we support them?
The next thing we're gonna do is support
and recognize team members' growth and development.
On your exam, you should expect questions
where team members
is gonna have issues.
One or two members may have an issue on something.
The answer is to train them.
They don't know how to do something, coach them.
They don't understand something, coach them.
They don't know how to use the tools,
make sure they're trained correctly.
This will help them to grow.
Team members not knowing how to do something
can become frustrating to them,
and it will slow down the team's velocity.
Team members should be willing to ask each other for help
in case needed.
That's the support of the Agile project.
The next thing you wanna do
is determine the appropriate feedback and approach.
We just talked about this.
We wanna make sure that whatever it is with this team,
if they're having issues, we're gonna get it resolved.
If they need particular tools, we'll help get it for them.
If they need training, we'll help get it for them.
Once they're working,
we have to verify performance improvements.
Once you have given the team the tools they need,
the training they need, look back at those APIs.
Look back at the performance they're doing
to see if their performance is getting better.
If you find their performance are not getting better,
then take more actions to ensure that it does get better.
Okay, so this is task three here, support team performance.
Remember, we wanna make sure that we assess them
against some kind of KPI.
Whatever they need, give it to them,
support them, train them, coach them.
Give them the right tools,
the right space, the right environment.
And then you wanna verify
that these performance improvements
are actually working
to ensure that the performance of the team
is going up and not down.

those strengths are,
you wanna make sure that you organize around them.

that they're gonna be held accountable

or the product backlog,
they should know,
hey, we selected that,
this is the work we're gonna get done,
the team had input in saying how much work can get done
in this timeframe, in this sprint iteration,
in this particular timeframe in a traditional project,
when the project executes,
they're now gonna be held accountable for that.
The next thing is you wanna determine and bestow
levels of decision making authority on the team.
We want to give them
the ability to make decisions, right?
Because you gotta remember something.
When a team makes a decision,
or comes up with a way to solve an issue,
or a way to do something,
like a way to program an application,
a method to paint a wall or something,
that's probably a practical way.
Team members see it in a practical way
because they're the one
that's actually gonna have to physically do it.
So give them that authority.
As a servant leader,
we are gonna bestow that level of authority
to our team members,
and that's gonna let them feel empowered.
Okay, the organization is dependent on us.
This is different, right?
Because in some projects
it may just be you don't bestow any authority making to them
and you're the one holding all the power,
and the team is always watching you of what to do next.
They look at you or what to do next.
In a servant leader, that's not the case.
They're doing the work,
and they're just hoping to get support from you.
They're determining the way to program that application,
they're just getting support from you.
Versus on some projects like regulatory projects,
high regulations, building a financial applications,
or parts of it, on a hybrid project, for example,
when the regulation starts to come into play,
you may not bestow authority on them.
So you have to know what that environment is,
what type of project you're working on,
before you start bestowing authority on them.
Okay, so really interesting task here.
Make sure you understand
that we wanna keep these team members empowered,
and we wanna make sure
that we give them the right level of decision making.

Do they learn best with a face-to-face

You have to know what's best for your team.
Speak with the team, engage the team, ask the team,
discuss with the team.
Then provide the training.
Then you have to evaluate
whether the training was effective or not.
So let's take a look at the particular enablers

We have to first determine what is it we want out

What particular competencies and elements

We have to determine,

We have to know, oh, they're using this new software tool

may start to use methods from an agile project.
So, we have to say to ourself,
"Okay, let's try an incremental procedure,
"so we can get more stakeholders engagement."
We can understand risk earlier,
we can get more lesson learned from it.
On your exam, I may have mentioned this before,
but on your exam,
remember that when you want customer feedback,
if you feel that in that question
that if the customers would've given more feedback,
it would've solved the problem,
then the answer is to use an incremental method.
Because the incremental method
or producing it in increments will lead
to the actual more engagement of the customers.
They're able to give you their reviews
and give you their feedback.
Okay, so just remember in today's world,
you have a couple different methods to choose from.
I'm not even gonna go into agile right now,
because there's just so many agile methods out there.
Don't forget, agile is an umbrella term.
There's so many agile methods that are out there.
And now combining them with a hybrid,
maybe we have an infinite number
of methods that are out there.
So, choose the one that's best for your project.

tasks.title: Establish project governance structure
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 2 Task 14: Establish project governance structure
tasks.content:
--- Domain 2 Task 14 ---

-: In this video,
I'm gonna be talking about Domain 2, Task 14,
Establish Project Governance.
Now, first of all, you have to understand
that we have something called corporate governance.
So corporate governance is basically
what you're gonna do to manage the organization
to produce value to its shareholders or to its owners.
In a project, it's basically the same definition.
It's what we're gonna do to the structure
of how we're going to manage the project
so we can produce value to our,
not shareholders, but to our stakeholders.
That's what this is about.
We have to come up with the right governance structure.
Maybe we could mimic what the organizational governance is,
incorporating organizational policies and procedures
into our project.
Remember something, on our projects,
we're not gonna throw away your organization policy.
Projects should incorporate
organization policies within them.
So, for example,
if the organization has a very particular policy
how changes should get done,
then the project may incorporate
those particular policies within it,
and that's how we're gonna manage change in our project.
If the organization has an escalation path
of how problems are handled
or how resolutions are situated or comes up with,
then maybe we wanna include that in our projects also.
Let's take a look at what it says here.
So, when it comes to defining a governance structure
of how the project would be laid out,
maybe you have your sponsor, you have your project manager,
you have your team members, your structure.
This is the escalation path.
This is how people get to the sponsor.
They talk to the project manager that talks to the sponsor.
These are the thresholds of how communications may be done
before it hits, before it goes up the ladder.
Remember, governance is all about
having that structure in place of how to manage a project.
So we want to determine
that appropriate governance for your project.
Maybe look at how the organization is designed.
There are some organizations that are very, very vertical.
In other words,
they have some huge escalation path that goes upwards.
You can't get to the CEO until you talk to Bob.
You can't get to Bob until you talk to Mary.
You can't get to Mary until you talk to Peter.
You can't get to, and it keeps on going.
Then there are organizations that are more horizontal,
where the CEO door may be open.
Here at TIA, my door is always open.
I am the boss here at TIA, and my door is open to everyone.
There's no escalation path.
The escalation path is, because we're a smaller business,
if you have an issue, you just come in and talk to me.
You don't have to talk to my assistant.
I have a lovely assistant.
She helps me out.
She's my right hand.
She does all my work for me.
She reminds me a lot of things, but you know what?
You don't need to go to her to talk to me.
There's no escalation path there.
So we have to define are there escalation paths,
and what is the threshold before you can go beyond someone?
Okay, you know what?
I've hit the threshold of this person.
Now I gotta go up.
So different projects, different, bigger business
may have that high escalation path.
Smaller ones may have a much lower escalation path.
Okay, so for your exam,
you wanna be able to determine
what governance is right for your project.
You wanna know what those escalation paths are
and the thresholds,
so when people know how to communicate,
they know who to communicate it to
and you wanna make sure that the governance structure
is appropriate for your project.

tasks.title: Manage project issues
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 2 Task 15: Manage project issues
tasks.content:
--- Domain 2 Task 15 ---

-: In this video,
I'm gonna be talking about Domain 2:Task 15,
manage project issues.
Now, issues are something that's happening on a project
that's probably gonna have
some kind of negative impact.
Issues can be things such as the supplier is late,
or that's all,
it's an ongoing thing where the supply is always late.
It could be a permit is being delayed.
It could be that a particular piece of the software
is failing the testing.
It could be a team member is having conflicts with others.
Issues are something
that's gonna always happen on a project.
Now, I do wanna differentiate risk and versus an issue.
What is the difference between risk and an issue?
So remember,
a risk is something that happens before an issue.
When a risk,
and when a risk happens and it's a negative risk,
it becomes an issue.
So a negative risk will turn into an issue.
If it materializes, I shouldn't say when.
I should say if a negative risk materializes itself,
it would become an issue.
So remember, an issue is generally a risk
before it becomes an issue.
We wanna be able to recognize when, if this, I should,
I keep saying when with risk.
If this risk happens that it will be an issue
then we want to be able to resolve it completely.
So here we go.
The first thing we wanna do is recognize
when a risk may become an issue.
When would the risk become an issue
that would need to be solved?
We would then ask ourselves, we wanna,
how do we attack this issue
with the optimal action to achieve success?
For example, if the supplier's consistently late,
how do we attack this issue?
Maybe do we call the supplier
and complain to them and try to see,
try to include them in resolutions with our team members
and see how can we come up with actions
that can lead to them being on time more?
Or maybe we can't.
Maybe the best solution is to just find a new supplier.
We have to determine what's the best action for the project.
Now remember, for the hundredth time,
collaborate, inclusive not exclusive,
collaborate with relevant stakeholders
on the approach to resolve the issue.
Notice it didn't say,
it didn't say in the objective for you to resolve it.
It says for you to collaborate, right?
We wanna collaborate with people to fix things.
As a PMBOK project manager, we don't fix anything.
You know, as an Agile project manager,
we don't fix anything.
We don't come up with solutions.
We collaborate with people
to have them come up with a solution.
Remember that for your exam,
and I keep saying this over and over,
and you guys are thinking I'm crazy right now,
but when you take your exam
and you do what I'm telling you,
you pass, you'll say,
"Okay, he knows what he was talking about."
Okay, so before we end this off,
you must recognize when a risk may become an issue.
You wanna attack that issue
with the right results to ensure project success.
And of course, when attacking it,
and choosing and the right solution,
make sure that you collaborate with the right stakeholders
to come up with the right solution.

tasks.title: Ensure knowledge transfer for project continuity
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 2 Task 16: Ensure knowledge transfer for project continuity
tasks.content:
--- Domain 2 Task 16 ---

Direct to manage project work,

What the testing team found,

Team members should help each other.

Confirm, confirm approach for knowledge transfer.
What exactly is your approach for this?
Putting in the lesson learned register,

The PMO gives it out to other projects.
Throughout a project in any organization,
there's gonna be a lot of knowledge gain,
maybe knowledge of how to build a particular product

When the project is done, this is,
this knowledge should be transferred

This is gonna help the organization best support

tasks.title: Plan and manage project/phase closure or transitions
tasks.fullTitle: Domain 2 Task 17: Plan and manage project/phase closure or transitions
tasks.content:
--- Domain 2 Task 17 ---

-: In this video,
I'm gonna be taking a look at Domain two: Task 17,
Plan and Manage Project Phase Closure or Transition.
So this is basically the last task
in domain two, by the way.
So it should end with closure.
Every project in its definition is gonna come to an end.
It has to come to an end.
It's not operations.
Operations is the opposite to a project.
It doesn't have an end date.
But projects has an end date,
so we know we're gonna have to close it out.
What are we doing when the project closes out?
Well, we're gonna wanna make sure
that this is series of tasks,
whether it's doing that final lesson learned.
If it's an Agile project,
you're gonna be doing your retrospective
that comes at the end.
You're gonna wanna make sure you pay off all the bills.
You're gonna wanna make sure
you release the resources that are there.
You're gonna wanna make sure
you archive the project records, and so on.
So there's quite a lot of things.
When a project is done,
it's not just, "Okay, everybody go home,
"let's all go and go to the bar,
"grab a couple of drinks and celebrate and we're done."
No, there's still a lot of work that has to get done
to formally and administratively close the project.
A formal closure procedure on both Agile
and traditional project is mandatory.
So let's see what it wants us to know.
So one of the things we're gonna have to do is
determine the criteria for successful close
to successfully close the project or phase.
When a phase is done or the project,
so remember when the final phase is done
you close a project,
but throughout the project
you're closing each individual phase.
So the coding phase is done, the testing phase is done.
What is the criteria to determine that that phase is done?
For example, in the testing phase
did the software has to meet a certain testing result
for it to be considered, finished or successfully tested?
When the coding phase was going on
did it had to meet a certain functionality
for it to be says, "Okay, we're done coding, right?"
What's that?
What's that criteria?
If you're building a house,
would it be the foundation?
That's one phase building the foundation.
Would it be passing a inspector,
getting a regulator or some kind of inspector
to come and pass it?
Is that when it's done?
I don't know.
It depends on the project, right?
You have to document that.
You have to say,
"Well this is the criteria
"that's gonna mark the end of this phase."
When this criteria is met, this phase is done.
When this criteria is met, this project is done.
Then you gotta validate the readiness for the transition.
Are we ready to transition from one phase to the next?
Are we ready to give this over to operations?
Maybe the testing team found errors
that cannot be fixed
and they're not ready to give it over
to the implementation team.
Maybe now it has to go back to coding to be fixed.
So we're gonna have to determine this.
Are we ready to move forward?
Are we ready?
You know, the, the, the testing team could be done.
We're ready to just to push it
into operations and maintain it.
But then we found so many bugs in testing
that we are saying software is not usable.
Let's pull it back.
Let's fix it.
Let's recode parts of it before we push it out.
It's not ready.
And then finally
we're gonna have to close this project down.
We're gonna have to conclude the actual closeout
of the project or the phase.
We're gonna do those final lesson learned.
This of course, is gonna get stored
and goes into the project management office
which is gonna then be given out
to the other projects.
Do the retrospective.
We're gonna learn what we did right, what we did wrong,
what we're gonna do more of, what we're gonna do less of.
We have to close out our procurement contracts.
We have to make sure
that whatever was in that contracts we're actually done.
We have to make sure that we pay them.
If there's any type of benchmarks
that has to be met by those vendors,
we wanna make sure it's done.
Financial, we must close all financial accounts.
Paying the project bills,
credit cards is gonna have to get done.
And you wanna make sure you release your resources.
Certain resources may be released
to go back to operational duties.
Some resource, some team members may be released completely
and have to go find all the projects
such as consultants would be like that.
So quite a lot to do
when you think about closing out your project.
It's not something that you're gonna do
any easy one-time thing.
You just can't walk away from a project
when the work is done.
It has to be administratively closed
or I should say it should be formally closed.
That way the organization know what to do
with the project records like archiving them.
That way other projects can then use the information
we learned from this project
to make those projects better.

at the second worst case

the education department with us, there's no w

Evaluate and Deliver Project Benefits and Value.
Let's get into it.
Why do companies do projects?
Because there's some value to gain.
Why do we do anything in life, first of all?
Because we want something.
We want something of value.
Why do we eat?
So the value is, so the food tastes good
and the value is we can stay alive.
Why does a organization implement
that new accounting system?
Because the value is, they can decrease their expenses

Why does Samsung build this beautiful phone that I'm using?

'cause I'm gonna buy it.
Why does organizations basically do things
to get some kind of value?

Projects is about delivering value to our stakeholders.

in other words.

decreases expense, more customer loyalty,
more customer happiness,
employee loyalty, employee happiness.

they're seeing some kind of value to this.

Why are we doing the project?

a couple of months ago

The benefits management plan,

The benefits management plan,
we're gonna have to doc what is the benefit we're getting?

Have ownership.
Let people know these are the benefits you're gonna get.

oh, with the benefits has been realized.
It's great benefits.

we can do it now within five minutes.

Have the customer comes in

iteration review minutes.
Evaluate those delivery options of to demonstrate value.

Let them know that,

Let them know repeatedly.
Let them see it.
Let them play with it.
Give it to them if you could if it's a agile project.

We provide value by conducting the work

We need to track it,
